column6: Operations and suppliers at significant risk for incidents of child labor
column8: Human Rights Resources and Energy collaborative
column13: WesCEF continues to be a member of the Human Rights Resources and Energy Collaborative (HRREc) group, with other companies such as Rio Tinto, South32, Alcoa, and BHP. The Group's primary objectives are to work collaboratively to consider wider labour rights issues and apply a human rights risk lens across the sector while identifying and developing good practices for human rights and modern slavery risk management.
column20: Human Rights Resources and Energy collaborative, labour rights issue, human rights risk

column6: Operations and suppliers ar significant risk for incidents of forced or compulsory labor
column13: In 2021, Wesfarmers undertook a process with an independent human rights adviser to determine its divisions' salient human rights issues. This analysis considered the concept of severity and its parts of scale, scope and irremediability, as elaborated in the Reporting Framework of the UNGP on Business and Human Rights.
column20: Human rights assessment, human rights issue, UNGP

Employee training on human rights policies or procedures
column13: Training team members is key to increasing alignment with Wesfarmers' minimum standards and reducing non-conformance risk. This year, more than 3,300 hours of training and education were delivered to team members on human rights (as established by the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and other international instruments), ethical sourcing risks and mitigation strategies, and ethical buying practices. Training was also provided to selected supply chain partners throughout the year, including as a component of the rollout of grievance mechanisms at new sites.
column20: Training, non-conformance risk, ethical sourcing risk

column6: Employee training on human rights policies or procedures
column8: Mineral Due Diligence and Cotton Transparency training
column13: Wesfarmers' Blackwood's sourcing teams participated in Mineral Due Diligence and Cotton Transparency training as new sourcing protocols were rolled out. Blackwoods also launched an updated Ethical Sourcing Policy, which was communicated to team members in August 2023, and supplier contracts have updated links.
column20: Mineral Due Diligence and Cotton Transparency training, sourcing protocol, Ethical Sourcing Policy

column6: Employee training on human rights policies or procedures
column13: A new animated ethical sourcing and modern slavery training video targeting Kmart Group suppliers and team members was developed. The training video explains Kmart and Target's modern slavery and ethical sourcing risks and how the Kmart Group Ethical Sourcing Program mitigates those risks.
column20: Ethical sourcing, modern slavery training, Ethical Sourcing Program

column6: Significant investment agreements and contracts that include human rights clauses or that underwent human rights screening
Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: Wesfarmers' Telethon Kids Institute is now in its 27th year, supporting the Wesfarmers Centre for Vaccines and Infectious Diseases, which leads research to prevent infectious diseases affecting Australian children and families. Among other priorities, current projects include a vaccine to prevent strep throat and rheumatic heart disease, which are highly prevalent in Indigenous communities.
column20: Telethon Kids Insitute, Centre for Vaccines and Infectious Diseases, vaccine

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: Wesfarmers' support of the Clontarf Foundation is in its twenty-third year, helping to provide education, life skills and employment opportunities for more than 10,000 Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander boys and young men nationwide. In that time, more than 1,500 young Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander men attending Clontarf Foundation academies have worked in a Wesfarmers business. During the year, Wesfarmers also supported measures to build awareness within Wesfarmers and across the community about the Uluru Statement from the Heart, including the proposal to establish an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice.
column14: More than 1,500 young Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander men attending Clontarf Foundation academies have worked in a Wesfarmers business.
column20: Clontarf Foundation, education, employment opportunity

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: WesCEF's Kleenheat sponsored Perth community and arts events Ã¢ÂÂ the Garden and Outdoor Living Festival, Good Food and Wine Show and Perth Fringe Festival- and donated to Telethon Community Cinemas. Kleenheat also celebrated three years of awarding community grants across regional Western Australia and the Northern Territory, granting $100,000.
column14: Kleenheat also celebrated three years of awarding community grants across regional Western Australia and the Northern Territory, granting $100,000.
column20: Perth community and arts event, Telethon Community Cinemas, community grant

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: WesCEF's Fertilisers continues its advocacy of regional West Australians and sustainable communities through its long-term partnerships with Hockey WA, the Country Women's Association and the Regional Remote Women's Network of WA. Agricultural education has always been a focus of CSBP Fertiliser, with the Nuffield Scholarship program supporting a scholar for two years to travel to study a topic of importance to their agricultural business, industry or community.
column20: Hockey WA, agricultural education, Nuffield Scholarship

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: WesCEF continues to support youth, environmental initiatives, science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) education and Aboriginal health and well-being programs in the Kwinana and Rockingham areas, including support of the local Clontarf Academy at Gilmore College for young Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students.
column20: STEM education, Aboriginal health and well-being, Clontarf Academy

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: Wesfarmers' Officeworks raised more than $920,000 in the 2023 financial year, with a further $22,600 raised in July 2023 through its Make a Difference Appeal. Officeworks continues raising funds to respond to its local communities' unique challenges to support 15 nationwide organisations. The fundraising efforts will help to ensure these organisations can continue their work within their local communities and help make a positive difference in the lives of children.
column14: Wesfarmers' Officeworks raised more than $920,000 in the 2023 financial year, with a further $22,600 raised in July 2023 through its Make a Difference Appeal.
column20: Make a Difference Appeal, local community, nationwide organisation

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: The Officeworks Stuart Park team members helped a preschool in the Indigenous community of Angurugu, located 650 kilometres east of the store in the East Arnhem region of the Northern Territory. Angurugu School is the first preschool in the area. It is supported by community Elders and volunteer teachers to enable students to learn about their culture and country in conjunction with early childhood development programs. To support the preschool students throughout the year and to cover the cost of educational materials, Officeworks Stuart Park donated more than $900 worth of educational and arts and crafts supplies to Angurugu School, including puzzles, activity sets, art smocks, paint sets, scrapbooks and wooden musical instruments.
column20: Angurugu School, childhood development, education material

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column9: The Australian Literacy and Numeracy Foundation
column13: Together with decade-long partners, The Australian Literacy and Numeracy Foundation (ALNF) and The Smith Family, Officeworks continues to identify opportunities and causes that support students who need it most. It includes helping to raise language, literacy and numeracy standards in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities across Australia through its partnership with ALNF and by helping to cover educational costs, such as books, excursions and uniforms through work with The Smith Family.
column20: The Australian Literacy and Numeracy Foundation, The Smith Family, educational cost

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: Wesfarmers' OnePass was an official supporter of Privacy Awareness Week (PAW) Ã¢ÂÂ an annual event led by the Office of the Australian Information Commissioner to raise awareness of privacy issues and the importance of protecting personal information.
column20: Privacy Awareness Week, Australian Information Commissioner, privacy issue

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: Since 2010, Wesfarmers' Blackwoods has partnered with The Fred Hollows Foundation to improve eye care and eyewear access. Blackwoods has donated 10 per cent of profits from selling PROSAFE eyewear, face shields and related accessories to The Foundation's Indigenous Australia Program.
column20: The Fred Hollows Foundation, eye care, eyewear access

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: NZ Safety Blackwoods supported KidsCan, with a portion of Tredlite product sales donated to the organisation. KidsCan is New Zealand's leading charity dedicated to helping children affected by poverty. The 2023 financial year was the fifth year of a five-year initial contract, with more than $500,000 raised. NZ Safety Blackwoods used its inventory reduction program to identify charities to which it could donate its slow-moving and obsolete stock. It contributed more than NZ$20,000 products to the Cyclone Gabrielle support efforts.
column14: It contributed more than NZ$20,000 products to the Cyclone Gabrielle support efforts.
column20: KidsCan, charity, poverty

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: Wesfarmers' Workwear Group's second year of a partnership with The Big Issue delivered benefits, including refreshed uniforms for street vendors, a stretch training program for the women distributing the magazine, team building opportunities, helping at the street soccer program, supporting The Big Sell, and raising funds for The Big Issue through a staff sample sale.
column20: The Big Issue, street vendor, stretch training program

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: In August 2022, Bunnings Trade partnered with industry-backed mental health and suicide prevention not-for-profit organisation MATES in Construction (MATES). To help raise awareness and vital funds, Bunnings Trade hosted a national Australian Trade BBQ in all stores for the first time. It released a co-branded, black version of the iconic Bunnings Trade hoodie, with all profits from sales going directly to MATES. Bunnings raised and contributed $500,000 from the hoodie sales, helping MATES to expand its reach in suicide prevention for the Australian construction industry.
column14: Bunnings raised and contributed $500,000 from the hoodie sales, helping MATES to expand its reach in suicide prevention for the Australian construction industry.
column20: MATES in Construction, awareness, vital fund

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: Bunnings is committed to improving mental health support by partnering with Movember in New Zealand in November 2022, where a limited edition, co-branded black hoodie was also released to help raise funds. The campaign raised over NZ$63,000 in funds for Movember, supporting the organisation to expand its grassroots support for suicide prevention and mental health in the community.
column20: Movember, mental health, suicide prevention

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: Bunnings supported community football clubs in partnership with the Australian Football League through the Bunnings Helping Hand Program, a national grants initiative developed to help clubs build and upgrade female-friendly facilities. It saw 10 $20,000 grants awarded to support clubs and the continued growth of the women's game at a local level. As part of Bunnings' partnership with New Zealand Rugby, the Bunnings Rugby Assist initiative was created to support the growth of grassroots rugby and make a meaningful difference to the wider community.
column20: Bunnings Helping Hand Program, female-friendly facility, community football club

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: In the lead-up to Christmas, Australian stores supported Share the Dignity's "It's in the Bag" campaign for the sixth consecutive year. Over two weeks, more than 67,000 bags of personal hygiene products were collected for women and girls experiencing homelessness and domestic violence. The bags were distributed to women and girls in need across Australia, helping to brighten their festive season.
